header.title: THEURGIA GOETIA BOOK II OF THE LEMEGETON

central_thesis: The Theurgia Goetia presents a comprehensive system for evoking and commanding a vast hierarchy of spirits, divided into fixed 'Kings/Princes' governing cardinal and intercardinal points and elements, and 'Wandering Princes' of the Air. These spirits, along with their numerous Dukes and Ministers, are compelled through specific seals, conjurations invoking divine names, and adherence to precise astrological timings and ritualistic preparations, enabling the practitioner to access hidden knowledge, perform various tasks, and exert influence over the material world.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces The Second Book of the Lemegeton, detailing the nature and offices of the Chief Spirits and their subordinates. It outlines the requirement of wearing a Lamen with the spirit's seal for obedience, describes the spirits' universal capabilities (revealing secrets, fetching, carrying, elemental control), and introduces the concept of good and evil spirits governed by Princes in fixed compass abodes. It emphasizes directing oneself towards the Prince's abode for successful operation and mentions general requirements like garments and materials are found in the first book, *Goetia*.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Figure of the 31 Kings or Princes
structure_content.summary: A compass rose diagram illustrates the orders and abodes of 31 Kings or Princes, associating them with cardinal/intercardinal directions and elemental qualities (Fire, Air, Earth, Water) and seasons. It notes that 20 Kings have fixed mansions, while others are movable. The diagram serves as a crucial reference for identifying a spirit's directional and elemental affinity.

Carnesiel is the chief Emperor of the East, commanding 1000 great Dukes, 100 lesser Dukes, and billions of ministring spirits. Only 12 chief Dukes and their seals are provided for practice. When Carnesiel is called, billions attend; when a Duke is called, 10-300 attend. A general conjuration formula is given, adapted for each Prince.

Caspiel is the chief Emperor of the South, overseeing 200 great Dukes, 400 lesser Dukes, and billions of ministring spirits. 12 chief Dukes are listed with their seals. Caspiel's Dukes are noted as stubborn and churlish, with each having 2660 subservient Dukes.

Amenadiel is the great Emperor of the West, with 300 great Dukes, 500 lesser Dukes, and innumerable ministring spirits. 12 chief Dukes are listed with their seals. A key instruction is given for timing: Amenadiel can be called anytime, but his Dukes (each with 3000 servants) must be called during specific planetary hours, following a successive daily/nightly cycle.

Demoriel is the great Emperor of the North, commanding 400 great Dukes, 600 lesser Dukes, and hundreds of trillions of servants. 12 chief Dukes and their seals are provided. Each Duke has 1140 servants, with more attending if greater work is required. The timing rule for Amenadiel's Dukes also applies to Demoriel's.

structure_content.chapter_title: Pamersiel, Spirit of the East (under Carnesiel)
structure_content.summary: Pamersiel is the first and chief Spirit under Carnesiel in the East, with 1000 spirits. His spirits are described as lofty, stubborn, evil, and false, not to be trusted for secrets, yet excellent for driving away Spirits of Darkness from haunted places. Calling Pamersiel or his 11 Dukes requires a magic circle, a Crystal Stone on Solomon's Table, and wearing the Lamen and Girdle. Repeated conjuration is necessary until the spirit appears.

structure_content.chapter_title: Padiel, Spirit of the East & By South (under Carnesiel)
structure_content.summary: Padiel governs 10,000 spirits by day and 200,000 by night. His spirits are naturally good and trustworthy, possessing power only granted by Padiel. No specific names or seals of his subordinate spirits are given, as they cannot appear without Padiel's leave. His seal is provided.

structure_content.chapter_title: Camuel, Spirit of the South East (under Carnesiel)
structure_content.summary: Camuel rules the Southeast, with Day and Night spirits mentioned. His spirits appear in beautiful, courteous forms both day and night. 10 Day Dukes and 10 Night Dukes are listed with varying numbers of servants (10 or 100, some none).

structure_content.chapter_title: Asteliel, Spirit of the South & by East (under Carnesiel)
structure_content.summary: Asteliel governs the South by East, with 10 Chief Day Spirits and 20 Chief Night Spirits. His spirits are described as very courteous, loving, and beautiful. 8 Day Dukes and 8 Night Dukes are listed, each with 20 servants. Day spirits are called during the day, Night spirits during the night.

structure_content.chapter_title: Barmiel, Spirit of the South (under Caspiel)
structure_content.summary: Barmiel, the first chief Spirit under Caspiel, rules the South, having 10 Day Dukes and 20 Night Dukes. All are good and willing to obey. 8 Day Dukes and 8 Night Dukes are listed with seals; some Night Dukes have no servants. Day/Night calling rules apply.

structure_content.chapter_title: Gediel, Spirit of the South & by West (under Caspiel)
structure_content.summary: Gediel is the second Spirit under Caspiel, ruling the South by West. He has 20 chief Day Spirits and 20 chief Night Spirits. His spirits are very loving, courteous, and willing. 8 Day Dukes and 8 Night Dukes are listed, each with 20 servants. Day/Night calling rules apply.

Asyriel rules the Southwest, with 20 great Day Dukes and 20 great Night Dukes. His spirits are good-natured and willing. 8 Day Dukes and 8 Night Dukes are listed, with servant counts varying from 10 to 40 per Duke. Day/Night calling rules apply.

structure_content.chapter_title: Maseriel, Spirit of the West & by South (under Caspiel)
structure_content.summary: Maseriel is the fourth Spirit under Caspiel, ruling the West by South. He has 12 chief Day Spirits and 12 chief Night Spirits, each with 30 servants. All his spirits are good-natured and willing. Day/Night calling rules apply based on the spirit's affiliation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Malgaras, Spirit of the West (under Amenadiel)
structure_content.summary: Malgaras is the first Spirit under Amenadiel, ruling the West, with 30 Day Dukes and 30 Night Dukes. His spirits are very courteous and willing, appearing two at a time with their servants. 12 Day Dukes and 12 Night Dukes are listed, with servant counts varying from 10 to 30 per Duke. Day/Night calling rules apply.

structure_content.chapter_title: Darochiel, Spirit of the West & by North (under Amenadiel)
structure_content.summary: Darochiel is the second Spirit under Amenadiel, ruling the West by North. He has 40 Day Dukes and 40 Night Dukes. 24 Day Dukes (12 before noon, 12 after noon) and 24 Night Dukes (12 before midnight, 12 after midnight) are listed. His spirits are good-natured and willing. Calling his Dukes requires observing planetary motions and specific planetary hours.

structure_content.chapter_title: Usiel, Spirit of the Northwest (under Amenadiel)
structure_content.summary: Usiel is the third Spirit under Amenadiel, ruling the Northwest. He has 40 diurnal and 40 nocturnal Dukes. 14 Day Dukes and 14 Night Dukes are mentioned. His spirits are very obedient and willing, with varying servant counts (10, 20, 40, or 630). They have powerful abilities related to hiding and discovering treasure, with specific instructions to create 4 seals on virgin parchment to protect hidden treasures.

structure_content.chapter_title: Cabariel, Spirit of the West & by North (under Amenadiel)
structure_content.summary: Cabariel is the fourth Spirit under Amenadiel, ruling the West by North, with 50 Day Dukes and 50 Night Dukes. 10 Chief Day Dukes and 10 Chief Night Dukes are listed, each with 50 servants. Day spirits are good and obedient; Night spirits are evil, disobedient, and deceptive, requiring caution when called in the night.

Raysiel rules the North, with 50 Day Dukes and 50 Night Dukes. 16 Chief Day Dukes are good and willing; 14 Chief Night Dukes are evil, stubborn, and unwilling. Servant counts vary (10-50). Day/Night calling rules apply based on the spirit's nature.

structure_content.chapter_title: Symiel, Spirit of the North & by East (under Demoriel)
structure_content.summary: Symiel is the second Spirit under Demoriel, ruling the North by East. He has 10 Day Dukes (good, obedient, 720 servants) and 10 Night Dukes (stubborn, unwilling, 790 servants). Day/Night calling rules apply, with servant numbers attending 'as occasion serves'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Armadiel, Spirit of the North East (under Demoriel)
structure_content.summary: Armadiel is the third Spirit under Demoriel, ruling the Northeast. He has many Dukes, with 15 Chief Dukes mentioned (1260 servants total). All his spirits are good and willing. They are called by dividing the day and night into 15 parts, beginning at sunrise for the first spirit and progressing successively.

structure_content.chapter_title: Baruchas, Spirit of the East & by North (under Demoriel)
structure_content.summary: Baruchas is the fourth Spirit under Demoriel, ruling the East by North. He has many Dukes, with 15 Chief Dukes mentioned (7040 servants total). All his spirits are good and willing. They are called by dividing the day and night into 15 parts, similar to Armadiel.

Geradiel is the first of the Wandering Princes who 'wandereth up & downe in the Ayre & never Continueth in one place.' He has 18,150 servants but no Dukes, thus is invoked alone. His servants appear in varying numbers (470 to 13,710) depending on the hour (day or night). They are all good and willing. A specific conjuration for Wandering Princes is provided, calling them to a Crystal Stone or Circle.

Buriel is the next Wandering Prince, with many Dukes and servants. His spirits are all evil, hated by other spirits, and appear 'Rugish' in the form of a serpent with a virgin's head, speaking with a man's voice. They are to be called only at night during specific planetary hours. 12 Dukes are listed with seals, each having 880 servants.

Hidriel is the third Wandering Prince, with 100 great Dukes, 200 lesser Dukes, and countless servants. 12 Chief Dukes (with 1320 servants) are mentioned. They appear as serpents with virgin heads but are courteous and willing. They delight in watery/moist places and are called day or night according to planetary motion.
Pirichiel is the fourth Wandering Prince, having no Dukes but 'Knights'. 8 Chief Knights (2000 servants) are mentioned. They are all good and willing, called according to planetary motion.

Emoniel is the fifth Wandering Prince, with 100 Princes/Chief Dukes and 20 Under Dukes. 12 Chief Dukes (with 1320 servants) are mentioned. His spirits are good and willing, called day or night according to planetary order, and primarily inhabit woods.

Icosiel is the sixth Wandering Prince, with 100 Dukes and 300 Companions. 15 Chief Dukes (with 2000 servants) are mentioned. His spirits are good-natured, appear mostly in houses, and are called in 15 parts throughout the day and night, from sunrise to sunset.

Soteriel is the seventh Wandering Prince, with 200 Dukes and 200 Companions whose locations change yearly. He has 12 Chief Dukes (6 for one year, 6 for the next), commanding 1840 servants. His spirits are good and obedient, called day or night according to planetary motion.

Menadiel is the eighth Wandering Prince, with 20 Dukes and 100 Companions. 6 Chief Dukes and 6 Under Dukes (with 300 servants) are mentioned. His spirits are good and obedient, called according to planetary motion, with a Duke in the first hour and a Companion in the next, successively through day and night.

Macariel is the ninth Wandering Prince, with 40 Dukes. 12 Chief Dukes (with 400 servants) are mentioned. His spirits are good and obedient, appearing in diverse forms, often as a dragon with a virgin's head. They are called day or night according to planetary order.

Vriel is the tenth Wandering Prince, with 10 Dukes and 100 Under Dukes. 10 Chief Dukes (with 650 servants) are mentioned. His spirits are evil, unwilling, and false, appearing as serpents with virgin heads. Caution is advised due to their deceptive nature.

Bydiel is the eleventh and last Wandering Prince, with 20 Chief Dukes and 200 other Dukes. 10 Chief Dukes (with 2400 servants) are mentioned. His spirits are good, willing, beautiful in human shape, and their offices and locations change yearly.

This section provides the full forms of conjurations for: 1) Wandering Princes, 2) Princes Governing Compass Points, 3) the Four Emperors, 4) Wandering Dukes (and other Dukes), and 5) Dukes under Compass Princes. These conjurations are highly detailed, invoking a vast array of divine names (Adonay, El, Elohim, Zebaoth, Tetragrammaton, etc.) and biblical events (Moses, Joshua) to command the spirit N to appear 'forthwith in a fair & comely shape' without harm, to fulfill the operator's will, and to provide rational, intelligible answers.

Upon appearance, the spirit is shown the Seal and Pentacle of Solomon. After receiving one's desire, the spirit is licensed to depart, with dismissal rites referenced as being in the first book, *Goetia*.

key_concepts.definition: High-ranking spirits ruling specific geographical/directional dominions (e.g., Carnesiel, Caspiel, Amenadiel, Demoriel) or described as 'Wandering Princes' of the Air. They command vast numbers of subordinate spirits and are themselves commanded by the operator. Some are fixed, others movable.

Subordinate spirits to the Emperors/Princes, often numbering in the thousands or billions. They carry out the specific tasks requested by the operator, sometimes having unique characteristics (stubborn, evil, good, courteous) and varying attendance numbers depending on the calling circumstances.

Unique sigils or emblems of individual spirits and their superiors. The Lamen, a breastplate bearing the spirit's seal, is crucial for compelling obedience. Seals are also used on magical tools and for specific purposes like treasure guarding.

key_concepts.term: Points of the Compass / Elemental Associations
key_concepts.definition: The system organizes spirits geographically (cardinal and intercardinal points) and elementally (Fire, Air, Earth, Water). Directing the conjuration towards the specific abode of the invoked Prince is a fundamental practical requirement.

Spirits are explicitly categorized as 'good' or 'evil' (or 'false'/'stubborn'). Good spirits are typically obedient and willing, while evil spirits may be deceptive, unwilling, or 'rugish,' requiring greater caution and often specified for night operations.

A specific, multi-part ritual invocation. It involves addressing the spirit by its title and name, stating the intent, directing it to appear in a specific location (Crystal Stone/Magic Circle) in a 'fair and comely shape' without harm, and compelling it through extensive lists of divine names and powerful biblical references.

A critical timing mechanism for calling Dukes. While Emperors may sometimes be called at any hour, their Dukes often have specific planetary hours (e.g., first two hours of the day, last two hours of the night) during which they are most effectively invoked. This links the system to astrological timing.

key_concepts.term: Crystal Stone / Secret Table of Solomon / Magic Circle
key_concepts.definition: Key ritual tools and spaces. The Crystal Stone (or speculum) is the medium for the spirit's appearance. The 'Secret Table of Solomon' is a specific table upon which the Crystal Stone is placed. The Magic Circle, mentioned as being detailed in Book 1 (Goetia), provides protective space for the operator.

A distinct category of spirits that 'wandereth up & downe in the Ayre & never Continueth in one place.' Unlike the fixed Princes of the Compass, their operations might involve different locational considerations, often associated with elemental Air, and some lack subordinate Dukes, being invoked alone with their servants.

practical_system.description: The Theurgia Goetia outlines a system for commanding a vast hierarchy of spirits, including Emperors, Kings, Princes, Dukes, and Ministring Spirits, categorized as either 'fixed' (governing specific compass points/elements) or 'wandering' (residing in the Air). The operator uses divine authority to compel these spirits to appear in a visible, audible, and affable form (often in a Crystal Stone or within a Magic Circle) to execute various tasks, ranging from revealing hidden knowledge to controlling elemental forces and guarding treasure.
tools: **Lamen**: A breastplate inscribed with the seal of the invoked spirit, worn by the operator to compel obedience.
**Seals / Characters**: Unique sigils for each Emperor, Prince, and Duke, used on the Lamen, other ritual items, and for specific magical applications (e.g., treasure guarding).
**Crystal Stone**: A 4-inch diameter crystal used as a scrying medium for the spirit to appear within.
**Secret Table of Solomon**: A specific table upon which the Crystal Stone is placed during invocation.
**Magic Circle**: A protective ritual boundary for the operator, whose construction is detailed in Book I (Goetia).
**Pentacle of Solomon**: A powerful magical device, described in Book I (Goetia), shown to the spirit upon its appearance to assert authority.
**Girdle**: Worn by the operator, as detailed in Book I (Goetia).
rituals: **Preparation**: Refer to Book I (Goetia) for general garments, materials, and the construction of the Magic Circle. Prepare a Lamen inscribed with the spirit's seal to be worn on the breast, and a 4-inch Crystal Stone set upon the Secret Table of Solomon, with the operator wearing a girdle.
**Directional Alignment**: For fixed spirits, the operator must orient themselves towards the specific point of the compass where the King/Prince has its abode.

**Timing (Planetary Hours)**: For Dukes and many Wandering Spirits, specific planetary hours of the day or night must be observed for effective invocation. Day spirits are called in the day, night spirits in the night, often with day/night cycles divided into parts.

**Conjuration**: Recite the specific conjuration formula for the desired spirit (Emperor, Prince, or Duke), filling in the spirit's name and relevant ruling titles/dominions. These conjurations are lengthy, repetitive, and invoke numerous divine names (Adonay, Zebaoth, Elohim, etc.) and biblical powers to compel appearance in a 'fair and comely Human shape' without harm.

**Appearance**: Spirits are expected to appear peaceably, visibly, and affably. If a spirit is stubborn or evil (as noted for certain categories), repeated conjuration may be necessary until it appears.
**Showing the Seal**: Upon appearance, the operator must show the spirit the Pentacle of Solomon (referenced from Book I) and its own seal, commanding its presence and obedience.
**Tasking**: Communicate the desired task or request to the spirit, which is expected to provide rational answers and fulfill commands.
**Dismissal**: After the task is completed and the operator's desire is fulfilled, the spirit must be licensed to depart using the dismissal rites found in Book I (Goetia).

relevant_quotes.text: The office of these Spirits is all one, for what one can do the others can do the same, they can show & discover all things that are hidden, and done in the world & can fetch & carry & do any thing that is to be done or contained in any of the 4 Ele-ments, Fire, Air, Earth or Water, & also the secrets of Kings or any other persons or person, let it be in what kind it will.

These are by nature good & evil, that is the one part is good & the other part is Evil, they are governed by their Princes, & each Prince hath his abode in the points of the Compass, as is showed in the following figure, therefore when you have a desire to call any of the Princes or any of their servants, you are to direct your self towards that point of the Compass the King or Prince has his mansion or place of Abode, & you cannot well err in your operations...

Note: these Spirits are by nature Evil & very false & not to be trusted in Secrets but are excellent in driving away Spirits of Darkness from any(thing) that is haunted (such) as houses, & to call forth Pamersiel or any of these his servants, make a circle in the form as is showed in the 1st. Book Goetia before going in the upper room of your house, or in a place that is Airy because these Spirits that are in this part are all Airy. You may call these Spirits into a Crystal Stone 4 inches (in) Diameter sett on a table made as followeth which is called the Secret Table of Solomon, having his seal on your breast & the girdle about your waist, as is showed in the Book Goetia, and you cannot err. The form of the table is this, when you have thus got what is to be prepared, rehearse the Conjuration following several times, that is whilst the Spirit comes, for without a doubt he will come.

I Conjure thee O thou Mighty & Potent Duke N, Who rulest under the Prince or King N, in the Dominion of the East, I Conjure thee N, that thou appear forthwith |^| alone or with thy servants, in this first [or second] hour of the day, here before me in this Crystal Stone [or before this Circle] in a fair & comely shape to do my will in all things that I shall desire or request of you. |*| I conjure & powerfully command you N by him that said the word & it was done & by all the holy & powerful names of God who is the only Creator of Heaven and Earth and Hell & what is Contained in them, Adonay, El, Elohim, Elohe, Elion, Escerchi, Zebaoth, Jah, Tetragram-maton Sadai... that you forthwith appear unto me here in this Crystal Stone [or here before this Circle] in a fair & comely Human shape without hurt to me or any other Creature that the great God Jehovah hath Created & made, and come ye peaceably, visibly and affably without delay Manifest-ing what I desire...

When he appears, show him the seal & pentacle of Solomon saying, 'Behold the Pentacle of Solomon which I have brought before your presence...' as it is showed in the first book Goetia at the latter end of the Conjurations, also when you have had your desire of the Spirit, license him to depart as is showed there in the book Goetia, &c.

critical_analysis.relevance: The Theurgia Goetia is a foundational text within the Solomonic grimoire tradition, representing the 'second book' of the Lemegeton. It bridges the overtly 'demonic' evocations of the Ars Goetia (Book I) with broader spirit categories, including elemental and aerial spirits often described as 'good' or 'mixed' in nature. Its meticulous listing of spirit hierarchies, seals, and specific conjurations provides a structured approach to spirit work that has influenced Hermetic Orders, Golden Dawn practitioners, and modern ceremonial magicians. It highlights the importance of precise ritual execution, divine authority, and the operator's Will in commanding spirits. Its inclusion of both 'fixed' and 'wandering' spirits demonstrates a sophisticated cosmology of the astral and elemental planes, essential for understanding the broader scope of practical magic.
critical_analysis.target_audience: This work is primarily intended for advanced practitioners of ceremonial magic, occultists studying historical grimoire traditions, and academic researchers in Western Esotericism. It assumes familiarity with fundamental magical concepts, ritual tools (like the magic circle and pentacle of Solomon, referenced from Book I), and a serious commitment to the demanding operative side of spirit evocation. It is not suitable for beginners due to its detailed instructions, complex spirit hierarchies, and the explicit mention of 'evil' and 'deceptive' spirits that require significant caution and experience to manage.
